title: Texting kills the postcard: How holiday habits have changed
text:
Texting kills the postcard: How holiday habits have changed Texting kills the postcard: How holiday habits have changed BRITISH holiday habits are changing, says a survey. PUBLISHED: 20:09, Tue, Aug 4, 2015 | UPDATED: 22:43, Tue, Aug 4, 2015 GETTY A third of Britons send text updates while on holiday 
We no longer use brochures from travel agents to choose where we are going. 
We don’t take travellers’ cheques abroad and our breaks are likely to be shorter than the traditional fortnight. 
Bringing home bottles of exotic foreign liqueurs is also a thing of the past. 
And the survey of 2,000 British adults for Teletextholidays found that three-quarters of us no longer send postcards. 
Instead, a third of holidaying Britons text updates while one in five email photos while still in the sun. 
And we are more active, with more than a third of us enjoying walking or hiking. 
The poll suggests were are also more open to trying foreign cuisine. 
Fewer than a fifth of us would bother to hunt for a British pub while abroad and nearly two-thirds claim to eat only the local dishes. 
The length of our holidays has also shortened. 
Some 41 per cent of us regularly taking a mix of one-week breaks and shorter trips throughout the year, rather than the more traditional two-week break. Related articles
